Award.AwardTitle: Reagent Controlled Selective Dehydrative Glycosylation Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Professor Clay S. Bennett of the Department of Chemistry at Tufts University is developing new, efficient chemical approaches to combine single sugar molecules into chains of sugars called oligosaccharides. Oligosaccharides are found on the surfaces of cells and are important in mediating immune system responses. Reagent kits are being developed for the general construction of well-defined oligosaccharides much faster than is currently possible and with the production of less waste. This research program impacts science and technologies that utlize oligosaccharides, including agriculture, biotechnology and pharmaceutical science. Professor Bennett's group has an ongoing commitment to training undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry research methods. They are also involved in outreach to Somerville, MA high school students by providing them with an introduction to organic chemistry and how it can be used to create biologically relevant molecules. The community of Somerville is diverse, so this program reaches many students from groups that are historically underrepresented in STEM fields.

Prof. Bennett is studying how to place the stereochemical outcome of a glycosylation reaction entirely under control of the promoter. For beta-selective glycosylations this involves activating hemiacetals with sulfonyl chlorides, while alpha-linked deoxy-sugars can be synthesized from hemiacetals using cyclopropenium cation promoted glycosylations. Three areas of investigation are being pursued: 1) an examination of the generality of this chemistry by exploring its compatibility with an array of deoxy-sugar coupling partners. 2) A study of the utility of this chemistry in the linear and convergent synthesis of penta- and hexasaccharides from natural products. 3) Studies to determine if this chemistry can be applied to the construction of beta-rhamnosides, an important class of carbohydrate linkages that currently cannot be synthesized directly in a single chemical transformation. Together, these studies may result in methods for the reliable stereoselective construction of difficult to access glycosidic linkages. Lessons learned from these studies also may permit the application of this chemistry to other classes of glycosides or even oligosaccharide and glycoconjugate libraries. Such libraries would open up new avenues for drug discovery and accelerate the pace of research in the field of glycobiology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Research Outcomes.

Complex carbohydrates and oligosaccharides play a host of critical roles in biology and medicine.  For example, the fact that the human immune system recognizes many bacterial surface polysaccharides as foreign has led to new ideas about immunotherapy.  On the other hand, it is also known that many bioactive natural products possess carbohydrates that are critical for their activity, and altering the composition of these carbohydrates can dramatically alter this activity.  The molecular basis of carbohydrate function is still poorly understood, however, largely due to the difficulties in synthesizing homogeneous material for study.  One of the largest challenges in oligosaccharide synthesis lies in controlling the stereochemical outcome of the glycosylation reactions used to string monosaccharides together.  This is because each glycosylation reaction can generate one of two possible isomers (termed a- and b-anomers), which can possess very different three-dimensional orientations and biological activity.  Controlling the selectivity in these reactions is very difficult, especially in the case of so called deoxy-sugars, which are an important component of many bioactive natural products.  The research supported by this grant allowed us to develop new stereoselective glycosylation chemistries and demonstrate their utility in oligosaccharide synthesis.  This latter point is particularly important, because while there are a number of methods for linking two monosaccharides together in model systems, the application of these technologies to real systems is not always possible.

Through these studies we developed new glycosylation chemistries for the stereoselective construction of a- and b-linked 2-deoxy-sugar disaccharides.  For a-selective reactions this involved using a combination of oxalyl bromide and cyclopropan-1-thiones to activate deoxy-sugar hemiacetals for a-selective glycosylations (see figure).  These same coupling partners could be activated using a combination of base and p-toluenesulfonyl chloride to provide b-selective glycosylation reactions.  Thus, we demonstrated that it is possible to change the stereochemical outcome of the glycosylation reaction simply by changing the coupling partners.  This is in contrast to conventional glycosylation chemistry, where completely different coupling partners are needed to change the stereochemical outcome of the reaction. 

More importantly, we have also demonstrated that this chemistry can be used for the synthesis of complex deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.  Using this chemistry, we have synthesized five different deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides with sized ranging from a trisaccharide (three sugars) to a hexasaccharide (six sugars).  Furthermore, we demonstrated the efficiency of this chemistry through the synthesis of the landomycin A hexasaccharide.  Prior to our efforts there had been four reported syntheses of this molecule, with overall yields ranging from >0.1% to 0.7%.  Using the chemistry developed in our lab we were able to complete the most efficient synthesis of this compound reported to date with an overall yield of 8.9%.  Due to the straightforward nature of this chemistry, and its demonstrable efficiency, we believe that this chemistry will greatly facilitate oligosaccharide synthesis.  Indeed, it has already begun to be adopted by other synthetic chemists to solve difficult problems in oligosaccharide construction.  Taken together, the chemistry developed through this grant has laid the foundations for next-generation methods for the rapid and routine construction of oligosaccharides.  Such technologies will be invaluable tools for understanding the roles that carbohydrates play in human health and well being.

In addition to its impact on organic synthesis and carbohydrate chemistry, the work funded under this grant has also helped train future scientists at several educational levels.  During the course of this grant the PI mentored eight graduate students, two of whom have obtained their Ph.D.  In addition, this research provided seven undergraduate students with the opportunity to carry out research.  The impact on the undergraduate students' education is evidenced by the fact that many of these students have gone on to top Ph.D. programs and medical schools.  Finally, a portion of the funds in this award has been used to carry out outreach programs with Tufts University's local host community of Somerville, MA.  We have worked with the Somerville High School AP chemistry class, where we have set up a workshop in which AP students travel to the Tufts University Department of Chemistry to carry out and analyze chemical reactions.  The goal of this program is to give students a more hands-on experience with chemistry in order to stimulate their desire to enter STEM fields.  Importantly, since our host community is diverse, many students from groups who are historically underrepresented in the sciences have taken part in these outreach activities.
